conclusion: The problem involves a detector moving along the positive direction of the x-axis with a velocity inversely proportional to its displacement.
The velocities at points A and B are given as 4 m/s and 2 m/s, respectively.
The displacement from point O to point B is 2 m.
The velocity is inversely proportional to the displacement, which can be expressed as \\( v = \frac{k}{x} \\).
The constant of proportionality \\( k \\) can be found using the given velocities.
The displacement from point O to point A is denoted as \\( x_A \\) and the displacement from point O to point B is \\( x_B \\).
The velocity at point A is 4 m/s and at point B is 2 m/s.
The velocity at point A is \\( v_A = \frac{k}{x_A} \\) and at point B is \\( v_B = \frac{k}{x_B} \\).
The constant \\( k \\) is found to be 4.
The displacement from point A to point B is \\( x_B - x_A = 2 - 1 = 1 \\) m.
The velocity as a function of displacement is \\( v(x) = \frac{4}{x} \\).
The time \\( t \\) taken to move from point A to point B is calculated by integrating the velocity function with respect to displacement.
The integral is set up as \\( t = \int_{x_A}^{x_B} \frac{1}{v(x)} \, dx \\).

The evaluated integral gives \\( t = \frac{1}{4} \left( \frac{2^2}{2} - \frac{1^2}{2} \right) = \frac{1}{4} \left( 2 - \frac{1}{2} \right) = \frac{1}{4} \left( \frac{4}{2} - \frac{1}{2} \right) = \frac{1}{4} \left( \frac{3}{2} \right) = \frac{3}{8} \\) seconds.
The time it takes for the detector to move from point A to point B is \\( \frac{3}{8} \\) seconds.
